Good job.... I do have one criticism. I've never found plug cutters to really hide very well.  An alternative that looks better (IMHO) is to take a branch of a tree with similar grain structure and sap content. Cut a piece of this small branch to a short length and drill an appropriately sized hole, even oblong the hole to fit the shape of the branch. Put glue in the hole pound the branch in and flush cut it to the beam. This is one way we used to hide holes in log homes.

This is why I love destin and mark. They both have the same idea. Not only do they teach science to the masses, not only do they show us why science important, but also they show us outcomes that are applied to our everyday life to make it more interesting and better. I got 2 examples. The first one isnt one most people would see as an interesting one. Mark rober worked for nasa before YouTube and he worked on 2 projects. One was curiosity and the other one was a satellite that scans the earth and gets results about natural events that will affect crops. The good thing about this is that nasa releases the results for free online so third world countries can be safe without having to pay in order to obtain this information. Second example is a quite interesting one. The internet started as a military tool designed to help them during any war. Just because we understand the physics of light and how to basically write information on the light wave we can have wireless connection to a world wide network of computers and servers. Also transistors exist partially because of space exploration. When nasa was designing the parts for the rocket that would send people in space the transistors that existed back then were too big so they designed new really smaller ones. So basically we owe science everything associated with technology like our smartphones and our computers. If you reached this far I know that most people in this comment section know all this but you should share it in places where people dont.

There are quite a few reasons why not to use old reclaimed barn wood in your house. They can carry many toxins and high levels of heavy metals, since old barns used to be sprayed down the wood with these heavy metals and toxins to try to keep pests and vermin from eating the wood of the barn. So every time you're disturbing it cutting it or bring it into your house you're exposing yourself to these heavy metals and toxins. You can always send a test sample of the wood into a lab for about $30 and they'll test it and tell you everything that's in the wood.  I recommend you do this before you bring this into your house.

Doesn't matter what you do to it, it will not look structural to anyone who knows about construction. We don't run drywall up to the side of a beam, can't finish the gap and you'd never run drywall on above a structural beam as drywall can't hold the weight of whatever the beam is supposedly supporting. The splits in the beam clearly show it isn't structural either, as you would have replaced it before the house collapsed on you. That said, your decorative antique wood beam looks very decorative. :)

a note on plugs in general:  Plugs are usually inserted cross grain, meaning the grain of the plug is 90 degrees to the wood it's going in.  It wouldn't make any difference in this job but if a thin piece had a plug put in it and the plug expanded under stress or moisture content, then it would split the wood.  Always put in plugs cross grain and it will look like you know what you are doing, regardless of the application.  From 45 years experience.

I added a 1790s log building to our 1850 farmhouse and I use hand hewn beams to tie the dry walled interior walls into the older structure. For our stair railing I split a hewn beam lengthwise to join the ends so it would be long enough. To do what that bandsaw did in a few seconds took me a circular saw, reciprocating saw, caulk line, router with homemade trammel, chisels, plane, and 8 hours.

Great video. One thing your supplier didn't mention: up north at least, there was a window between the hand hewn and the sawmilled beams where they were cut with a pit saw - a giant hand saw with a person standing on the log holding one end and a guy in a pit underneath holding the other. You still get the marks from the teeth, but they are straight and parallel marks. The guy getting rained on by sawdust all day long is also the origin of describing something as the pits.

If you buy old wood please make sure you deal with a reputable dealer.

A person whom I would like to spend an entire day with is Destin Sandlin, the host of the Youtube channel "SmarterEveryDay". He is an American engineer but uses his scientific knowledge to teach the Youtube community. He has an educational series called Smarter Every Day, where he asks questions and then conducts experiments on them with other scientists or just by himself. He knows a lot about astronomy, astrophysics, geology, physics, and many other types of sciences. Destin is an inspiration to me because I want to be like him when I grow up. I love science, but in particular, astrophysics, I love space and I would love to apply my knowledge of science to space. I helped a friend do something similar in his home a few years ago. He had pulled down an old barn and some granaries on his property. The wood, all hand planed, didn't go to waste. His hardwood floor looks amazing. We placed upright beams against the walls, under the ones on the ceiling. Most of them we had cut in half, so they look like they're part of the walls or ceiling. Destin, Another note on your old beams...if they were maple and the ring radius denotes the tree was fairly large, that was likely virgin timber. Thanks for sharing! It is amazing what craftsmen did centuries ago, especially when you consider the tools they had. I was fortunate to be in Boston years ago when the U.S.S. Constitution was being refitted.  They had removed the masts, etc. and had laid them sideways in a nearby parking lot.  When sail boats were constructed then shipwrights would put coins into the hole were a mast was going to be placed.  In the parking lot you could see the bottom of the masts and literally see every detail of the coins in the wood. You could make out the image and the date.  Amazing.  And, I was given a ship's nail off of the U.S.S Constitution, because they removed and replaced a lot of components like that during the refit.

This may be the intersection of the architect and engineer in me, but everything about this really just... niggles me. A lot. :x My sense of architectural aesthetics intersects directly with structural engineering, and I like to see architectural elements that are simultaneously structural AND decorative. Not just a pretty hand-hewn beam anchored into the ceiling just to look structural, but a pretty hand-hewn beam that IS structural, and it's exposed so that its beauty and function can be admired.

But then again I also grew up in a log cabin in which the entirety of its structural elements were exposed. The immense logs that made up its foot-thick walls and mortar that filled the gaps between them, the immense sawn logs that spanned the width of the house to support the second floor, the A-frame elements of the roof (which both bedrooms nestled under), and so on.

So to me, when I see something that has not only form but also genuine, real, usable function, I squee inside. I get an architectural and engineering high from it. It's also why I really enjoy the aesthetics of furniture, because furniture has both form and function.
This was just a genuinely cool video.

Devin, I tore down a big house built in 1875 by hand.  The framing of the structure was amazing, all pegged hand-made mortise and tenons.  The white pine posts went from the ground to the 2 story roofline, and the horizontal 12X12s spanned the entire walls.  I made a few videos on my channel if you're interested in seeing the process.  I used the reclaimed lumber tu build a garage, but had a huge pile left over!
